channel.title: Your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps?
channel.description:
Recently bought Nexus 5, was also considering some top Lumia. Planning to make some apps maybe, with a C++ backend of course.
What's your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps? Do the latter two tend to perform faster? Some iOS developers at my company claimed that the same Android front-ends perform slower (usually whenever the company writes an app there will be a version for every platform). Maybe the Android developers were just bad, not sure.

item.title: Your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:4, topic:541909”]Native programming is rarely needed for Android apps. Intensive games are the only thing that you might want to write the majority of the core in c/c++. It brings more complexity than is worth for other apps![/quote]Please don’t tell Enforcer not to write C++.

Read full topic

item.title: Your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Native programming is rarely needed for Android apps. Intensive games are the only thing that you might want to write the majority of the core in c/c++. It brings more complexity than is worth for other apps!

Read full topic
item.source: Your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps?

item.title: Your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps?
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:541909”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=660779.msg4417630#msg4417630 date=1396720987]
Android front-ends perform slower
[/quote]

with a C++ backend of course.

And you wonder why…

Android’s major problem is version fragmentation and not so strict design policy - ultimately these two things go hand in hand. You’ve obviously used all the Google apps, aren’t they absolutely great? Simple, clean interface that’s nice and smooth. The reason: Google develop them with their current iteration of Android in mind and actually follow their guidelines (It’d be quite weird if they didn’t)

Some may argue the freedom Android developers are given to design their applications in almost any way they feel like is a plus side. For the majority of apps this level of customisation is entirely unnecessary and leads to awfully equivocal interfaces which even tech-literates may find difficult to adapt to. iOS and Windows phone have a much healthier approach by making developers use their own native components to build apps - I love how WhatsApp and normal text conversations look almost identical in Windows Phone.

tl;dr Android devs are given too much freedom and some get it wrong hence make shitty slow interfaces.[/quote]

Alright. Anyway, the problems were on the Java side. I have actually written some core components in C++ that are used for all the mobile frontends, and that performs very fast on Android.

Read full topic
item.source: Your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps?

item.title: Your experience with Android vs equivalent Windows Phone 8 / iOS apps?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

The Enforcer:

Android front-ends perform slower

The Enforcer:

with a C++ backend of course.

And you wonder why…

Android’s major problem is version fragmentation and not so strict design policy - ultimately these two things go hand in hand. You’ve obviously used all the Google apps, aren’t they absolutely great? Simple, clean interface that’s nice and smooth. The reason: Google develop them with their current iteration of Android in mind and actually follow their guidelines (It’d be quite weird if they didn’t)

Some may argue the freedom Android developers are given to design their applications in almost any way they feel like is a plus side. For the majority of apps this level of customisation is entirely unnecessary and leads to awfully equivocal interfaces which even tech-literates may find difficult to adapt to. iOS and Windows phone have a much healthier approach by making developers use their own native components to build apps - I love how WhatsApp and normal text conversations look almost identical in Windows Phone.

tl;dr Android devs are given too much freedom and some get it wrong hence make shitty slow interfaces.

Read full topic
